articles.headline: In Asia, a Gulf’s Worth of Oil Awaits Transport
articles.snippet: The Tengiz field has been operating at half its capacity because Russia hasn’t cooperated with pipeline expansion agreements.
articles.abstract: The Tengiz field has been operating at half its capacity because Russia hasn’t cooperated with pipeline expansion agreements.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATYRAU, Kazakhstan  Even as the petroleum industry continues drilling in the Gulf of Mexico at considerable expense and risk, a single field here in Central Asia stands ready to produce two-thirds as much oil each day as the entire gulf does, with less danger to the environment.

articles.headline: She’s a Candidate for a Job She Devised
articles.snippet: Elizabeth Warren, who proposed the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, would be a dynamic choice to lead it.
articles.abstract: Elizabeth Warren, who proposed the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, would be a dynamic choice to lead it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can Mary and Elizabeth remake the financial world for consumers?

articles.headline: Federal Report Faults Banks on Huge Bonuses
articles.snippet: Citigroup and Goldman Sachs are among 17 companies said to have made lavish and unmerited payouts.
articles.abstract: Citigroup and Goldman Sachs are among 17 companies said to have made lavish and unmerited payouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the financial system on the verge of collapse in late 2008, a group of troubled banks doled out more than $2 billion in bonuses and other payments to their highest earners. Now, the federal authority on banker pay says that nearly 80 percent of that sum was unmerited.

articles.headline: Fiat Pushes Work Ethic at Italian Plant
articles.snippet: The car maker is asking workers to be more devoted to their jobs, mirroring a larger effort by the government.
articles.abstract: The car maker is asking workers to be more devoted to their jobs, mirroring a larger effort by the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: POMIGLIANO D’ARCO, Italy  In a country where Fiats line the streets, Italians have long clung to a revealing proverb: as Fiat goes, so goes Italy.

articles.headline: Pentagon Faces Growing Pressures to Trim Budget
articles.snippet: Political and economic factors are forcing the first serious debate since 2001 about the size and cost of the military.
articles.abstract: Political and economic factors are forcing the first serious debate since 2001 about the size and cost of the military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After nearly a decade of rapid increases in military spending, the Pentagon is facing intensifying political and economic pressures to restrain its budget, setting up the first serious debate since the terrorist attacks of 2001 about the size and cost of the armed services.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Dell to Pay $100 Million Settlement
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Dell of misleading investors by using money it had received from Intel to pad its quarterly earnings statements.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Dell of misleading investors by using money it had received from Intel to pad its quarterly earnings statements.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dell, several former executives, and its founder, Michael S. Dell, agreed Thursday to pay more than $100 million in penalties to settle charges of disclosure accounting fraud filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

articles.headline: Mortgage Securities It Holds Pose Sticky Problem for Fed
articles.snippet: Keeping the securities could cost the central bank money and make it harder to fight inflation, while selling them could drain money from the economy.
articles.abstract: Keeping the securities could cost the central bank money and make it harder to fight inflation, while selling them could drain money from the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve provided most of the money for new mortgages in the United States last year, effectively lending more than $1 trillion to American homeowners.

articles.headline: More of the Rich Run as Populist Outsiders
articles.snippet: As voters express outrage at bailouts, more candidates are spending a fortune to remake themselves into insurgents.
articles.abstract: As voters express outrage at bailouts, more candidates are spending a fortune to remake themselves into insurgents.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI  When Jeff Greene, a k a the Meltdown Mogul, recently brought his Democratic campaign for the United States Senate to a poor Miami neighborhood rife with the kinds of subprime mortgages that he became a billionaire betting against, did he:
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Michael Luo

articles.headline: Oil Rig’s Siren Was Kept Silent, Technician Says
articles.snippet: The alarm was not fully activated to avoid waking up the crew, and so did not sound during the disaster.
articles.abstract: The alarm was not fully activated to avoid waking up the crew, and so did not sound during the disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: KENNER, La.  The emergency alarm on the Deepwater Horizon was not fully activated the day the oil rig caught fire and exploded, killing 11 people and setting off the massive spill in the Gulf of Mexico, a rig worker on Friday told a government panel investigating the accident.
